items.title: BOLM high resolution land use and land cover dataset and benchmark results for the rapidly developing City of Dhaka Bangladesh
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 28 October 2025

BOLM high resolution land use and land cover dataset and benchmark results for the rapidly developing City of Dhaka Bangladesh
                    Ovi Paul1, Abu Bakar Siddik Nayem1, Anis Sarker1, Rakibul Hasan Rajib1, Tahmid Hossain Jit1, Armun Alam1, M. Ashraful Amin1, Amin Ahsan Ali1 & …AKM Mahbubur Rahman1 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 37689 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingEnvironmental impact

AbstractLand use land cover (LULC) mapping using deep learning greatly enhances our understanding of geographic, socioeconomic, and urban development patterns. However, annotated satellite data are scarce in developing countries in South and East Asia due to funding and urban heterogeneity. We present the Bangladesh Open LULC Map (BOLM), a high-resolution dataset with pixel-level annotations across eleven classes for the Dhaka metropolitan area and surrounding regions (4,392 \(\hbox {km}^2\), 891 million pixels). Annotations were generated using high-resolution Bing imagery following a rigorous, multi-stage validation process supported by GIS experts. Although Bing data provides fine spatial detail for visual interpretation, multispectral data remain essential for spectral analysis and temporal monitoring. We benchmarked DeepLabV3+, HRNetv2, U-net, UnimatchV2 and Segmenter ViT-16 on five merged LULC classes, achieving an overall IoU of 0.50 and F1 score of 0.66 with the UnimatchV2. Further experiments using Sentinel-2A data highlight the trade-off between spatial and spectral resolution. Our results show that while DeepLabV3+ and HRNet are effective for LULC mapping, other models such as U-Net, Segmenter, and UniMatchV2 perform even better, highlighting the model-agnostic nature of our study. The BOLM dataset can support future deep learning models and domain adaptation for LULC tasks in data-scarce regions, addressing the critical gap of high-quality LULC data in South and East Asia.

IntroductionLULC changes have gained significant attention due to rapid global ecosystem transformations1. Developing countries in South and East Asia are experiencing notable changes in LULC2,3. In recent decades, vegetation types such as grasslands, woodlands, and bushlands have been increasingly converted into agricultural and settlement areas to meet the needs of growing populations4. Land cover refers to the physical material on the Earth’s surface, such as forest, mountain, desert, or water5. Land use describes how humans utilize land for socio-economic purposes, such as farming or urban development6,7. Monitoring changes in LULC over time provides insights into geography, socio-economic conditions, poverty levels, and urban expansion8. Recently, deep learning techniques have shown promise in extracting LULC information from satellite imagery, and have been widely adopted for such applications9,10. This paper introduces the BOLM, a dataset designed to address the lack of annotated LULC data for developing countries, particularly in South and East Asia. To effectively apply deep learning methods for LULC mapping in South and East Asian countries (e.g., Bangladesh, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, India, Sri Lanka), we identify three major challenges.Table 1 Summary of the LULC satellite datasets from developing countries.Full size tableFirst, there is a lack of annotated satellite imagery with pixel-level ground truth for LULC. Such annotations are essential for training deep models, especially for high-resolution tasks. While many datasets have been developed in wealthier countries with substantial funding18,19,20,21,22, their transferability to developing countries is limited23. Variations in building materials, landscape, and cultural practices impact model performance across regions23. Moreover, only a few LULC datasets exist for developing countries9,11,12,16,17. OpenEarthMap13 provides unmanned aerial vehicle(UAV) imagery from a limited number of developing cities (e.g., Dhaka, Cox’s Bazar). However, UAV data collection is expensive and infrequent in Bangladesh. Additionally, OpenEarthMap lacks annotated data for most of South and Southeast Asia. Thus, pixel-level LULC annotations using high-resolution satellite imagery are critical for regions like Bangladesh.Second, Table 1 shows that most datasets in the region are low-resolution (10m, 15 m, 30 m). For example, datasets in India11,12 use coarse resolutions and limited class definitions. These patch-based annotations introduce significant errors when applied to densely populated and unstructured urban environments. In contrast to developed nations, many cities in developing countries lack planned zoning, and features such as houses, tree canopies, waterbodies, and grasslands are smaller and more fragmented. Although the World Bank dataset covers the Dhaka metropolitan area17, it lacks the detail needed for pixel-wise classification (see Fig. 1).Third, most deep learning models rely on RGB channels24 and outperform traditional methods25,26. While Bing and Google offer high-resolution RGB imagery, updates for developing regions are infrequent27,28. Meanwhile, satellites like Sentinel-2/3 or Landsat offer regular low-resolution imagery with multiple spectral bands. Remote sensing research has long used indices such as NDVI, NDWI, and RVI derived from these bands to identify land cover29,30. Thus, incorporating multi-spectral data in deep learning can be beneficial even with lower resolution.Fig. 1Comparison between World Bank and BOLM(ours) Ground Truth (Here red color represents various kinds of built-up, cyan represents forest/tree cover, yellow represents bare land/meadow, and blue represents water). Map created by the authors using data from31. Maps were modified using the Lucid web application (https://lucid.app/).Full size imageThis paper contributes the BOLM, a high-resolution dataset with pixel-level annotations for 11 classes. BOLM covers approximately 4,392 square kilometers in the Dhaka region, including urban and surrounding rural areas. Annotations were generated using Bing imagery and a rigorous process to ensure accuracy. Due to its resolution and detail, BOLM is suitable for training and domain adaptation in South and Southeast Asian countries with similar landscapes. Finally, we evaluate the performance of DeepLabV3+32 using Sentinel-2A data, low-resolution, and Bing data (high-resolution). Sentinel-2A experiments include band combinations (e.g., Atmospheric Penetration, False Color Infrared, Shortwave Infrared) and index images (e.g., NDVI, NDWI, RVI), assessed using the same BOLM ground truth. Benchmark results and comarison are also reported on Bing imagery with the U-net33 UnimatchV234, HRNet-V235 and Segmenter (base ViT-16)36 to demonstrate performance with high-resolution data alongside the Deeplabv3+ which we have employed thoughout the study. We conclude with recommendations on using BOLM with both low spatial resolution of Sentinel-2 and high spatial resolution of Bing data for LULC classification in developing regions.Fig. 2Workflow visualizing the data annotation pipeline and experimental setup, from satellite image acquisition to model evaluation.Full size imageTo provide a comprehensive overview of the approach taken in this study, Fig. 2 presents the workflow for data annotation, model training, and evaluation. It illustrates how high-resolution satellite images from Bing and multispectral Sentinel-2A data were processed and annotated, followed by training and testing of deep learning models, and concluding with a detailed performance comparison. This workflow highlights the rigorous multi-step process and the integration of spatial and spectral information to achieve accurate LULC mapping.Existing datasets and their limitationsExisting LULC datasetsSeveral high-quality LULC datasets are publicly available, most of which originate from developed regions. The Potsdam and Vaihingen datasets, for example, cover areas in Germany and include classes such as buildings, low vegetation, trees, cars, and background18. The Gaofen Image Dataset (GID), based on imagery from various regions in China, contains five classes: forest, built-up, farmland, meadow, and water21. LoveDA22 (Land-cOVEr Domain Adaptive) contains high-resolution annotations from both urban and rural scenes in China. MiniFrance20 provides annotations for urban and rural environments in France. FloodNet19, created using data collected during floods in Texas and Louisiana (USA), includes ten classes, one of which is background.Among developing countries, India has produced datasets such as In-Sat and IndiaSat. In-Sat uses Sentinel-2 and Google Earth imagery for applications such as environmental monitoring, urban planning, and LULC classification11. IndiaSat contains 180,414 labeled pixels across four land cover classes: greenery, water bodies, barren land, and built-up areas, derived from Landsat-7, Landsat-8, and Sentinel-212. In Africa, the Mpologoma catchment dataset37 from eastern Uganda combines satellite and ancillary data (e.g., aerial imagery and ground truth) collected between July and November 2019. Another example is from Ethiopia9, where LULC changes were studied in the Libokemkem district of South Gondar using images from 1973, 1985, 1995, 2003, and 2015.LandCoverNet15 is a global dataset developed using Sentinel-2 imagery at 10-meter resolution. It consists of geographically diverse 256\(\times\)256 pixel patches annotated through human consensus, spanning Africa, Asia, Australia, Europe, and the Americas. In Vietnam16, analyzed the urban expansion of Hanoi using Landsat imagery from 1989 to 2019. The study highlights urban growth driven by economic reforms, with urban areas replacing agricultural land and water bodies. It categorizes land into seven classes and underscores the effectiveness of remote sensing for urban monitoring.Limitations in current datasetsDespite the availability of some datasets from developing countries (see Table 1), several critical limitations remain.First, many datasets have low spatial resolution (10–30 meters). In dense and unstructured urban settings found in developing cities, features such as houses, tree canopies, waterbodies, roads, and grasslands are small and fragmented. These details are often lost in low-resolution imagery, making accurate LULC classification using deep models challenging.Second23, emphasizes that due to variations in building materials, culture, and geographic features, LULC models trained on cities in one region often perform poorly when applied to cities in other regions, particularly in South Asia. Deep models are sensitive to such domain shifts. Therefore, high-resolution pixel-level annotations are necessary to develop robust domain adaptation models for developing countries.Finally, LULC datasets from Bangladesh present unique challenges. Annotations are often created using tools such as QGIS or ArcGIS with coarse boundaries, leading to mislabeled pixels. These inaccuracies can significantly degrade model performance, especially for pixel-wise learning. For instance, although the World Bank developed an urban map of Dhaka17, the dataset lacks granularity. It includes broad categories like construction sites or airports that are hard to differentiate visually. Major limitations of this dataset include: (a) coarse annotations with merged classes; (b) coverage limited to urban areas; and (c) restricted access due to proprietary satellite sources (QuickBird, Pleiades, Landsat, Sentinel).About limitation (a), Fig. 1 shows that in our ground truth, the cyan regions represent forest/tree cover, whereas in the World Bank annotations, such areas are merged with built-up classes. This is especially problematic in Bangladesh, where densely packed artificial structures coexist with natural features such as rivers and forests. Regarding (b), the World Bank dataset only covers the Dhaka metropolitan area and excludes rural regions. For (c), the data is not freely available for academic or public use, limiting research accessibility.Dataset collection and annotation proceduresThis section outlines the satellite imagery sources, geographic coverage, and annotation procedures used in the BOLM dataset. The study area covers the Dhaka Division, with the city of Dhaka centrally located. The satellite image tile spans from the upper left corner at N24°23\('\)04\(''\), E89°57\('\)26\(''\) to the lower right corner at N23°22\('\)13\(''\), E91°00\('\)26\(''\), forming a rectangular area of approximately 117 km by 124 km.Sources of dataTwo types of satellite imagery were used in this study. Bing imagery was preferred for the annotation because it has fine resolution that improves annotation accuracy, especially for a dense city like Dhaka. In Dhaka, urban elements such as closely spaced buildings, water bodies, and vegetation overlap; the finer resolution allows for more precise annotation of individual features that are often indistinguishable in Sentinel-2’s coarser resolution. This improved detail helps the accurate identification of diverse building materials and enhances the differentiation between residential and commercial areas. The precise mapping of overlapping urban elements in Dhaka increases the reliability of land-use and land-cover assessments, making Bing imagery an ideal tool for urban analysis in developing cities. Sentinel-2A imagery was used for additional segmentation experiments involving various band combinations and indices.Bing dataBing provides high-resolution aerial imagery at 2.22 meters per pixel (zoom level 17)38. The imagery used in this study was acquired on 20 April 2019 and was provided as a single RGB TIFF tile with a resolution of 48,906\(\times\)47,256 pixels. Figure 3 shows the full image tile; the blue rectangle marks the annotated region encompassing Dhaka Division, while the red rectangle indicates the Dhaka city subregion used for testing.Fig. 3(a) is the input image from Bing used, and (b) is the corresponding ground truth. Map created by the authors using data from31 and maps were modified using QGIS version 3.10.1039.Full size imageSentinel-2A dataSentinel-2A imagery was acquired on 11 April 2019 (Tile ID: L1C_T45QZG_A016175_20190411T043829). This imagery contains 12 bands with spatial resolutions ranging from 10 to 60 meters. Red (B4), Green (B3), Blue (B2), and Near-Infrared (B8) bands are captured at 10 m resolution, while Coastal Aerosol (B1), Water Vapor (B9), and SWIR Cirrus (B10) are captured at 60 m resolution.Sentinel-2A Channel and Index CombinationsTable 2 Sentinel-2 Index and Combination RGB Channel Formation.Full size tableMultispectral data from Sentinel-2A were resampled to 10 m resolution using bilinear interpolation40. RGB composites for each combination and index were generated using QGIS according to Table 2. These combinations, including NDVI41, NDWI42, and RVI42, are effective for enhancing class separability in vegetation and water-rich environments. These images are shown in Fig. 4.Fig. 4Combination and index images generated from Sentinel-2A multispectral bands. Maps were generated by using data from Sentinel-2 imagery43.Full size imageAnnotation processWe opt for a 3-stage annotation4445 process that involves at least two people annotating one image and additional review where the classifications differ. The detailed annotation and validation process is discussed later in this section. Bing imagery was used for the LULC annotation. Due to the large image size, it was divided into a 33\(\times\)33 grids, resulting in 1,089 sub-images of 1,500\(\times\)1,500 pixels. Sub-images from each vertical column were grouped into one of 33 folders. Annotation was performed on folders 8 through 19, totaling 396 sub-images covering Dhaka city and surrounding areas. Two annotators per folder resulted in 24 annotators overall. The full list of LULC class description is included in the supplementary Table S8.Annotation trainingTraining included two phases:Technical Training: A technical session was conducted to present the detailed annotation procedures and demonstrate the use of eCognition. This session covered rule-set creation, image segmentation, class labeling, and the process of exporting the final annotated outputs. To support the annotators throughout the annotation period, a tutorial video was prepared and made accessible for reference https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=psQwvRDxuTo. A remote sensing expert was present along with the authors during the session to provide guidance and ensure the accuracy and consistency of the annotation process.Non-Technical Training: Authors and experts hosted multiple sessions to explain the differences between LULC classes and provide example cases.Fig. 5Full ground truth of the Bing-Dhaka dataset. Map created by the authors using data from31. Maps were modified using Trimble eCognition Developer version 10.4 (https://geospatial.trimble.com/en/products/software/trimble-ecognition).Full size imageProcessing with eCognitionAnnotation of the Bing-Dhaka dataset was carried out using Trimble eCognition Developer version 10.4 (https://geospatial.trimble.com/en/products/software/trimble-ecognition) with a predefined rule set designed for eleven LULC classes. For each sub-image, the rule set was loaded, and multi-resolution segmentation was applied to divide the image into small polygonal objects. This segmentation process used image layer weights of 1:1:1 and was governed by homogeneity parameters: a shape factor of 0.1 and a compactness factor of 0.5. After segmentation, polygons were interactively labeled with class-specific colors to ensure consistency and accuracy. All steps, including segmentation, labeling, and merging, were conducted within the eCognition environment. Once labeling was complete, adjacent polygons belonging to the same class were merged using the software’s merge function. The final annotated sub-image was then exported using the export function defined in the rule set. The final result is shown in Figure 5. Fig. 5 a, b, c show the snapshots for the image upload and polygon segmentation using the eCognition software.Data validation and reliabilityFollowing the study of Ramos et al.46, three-stage validation is done to ensure annotation quality in BOLM. Stage 1 compared annotations from two groups, identifying key disagreements. Stage 2 refined those regions through collaborative re-annotation. In Stage 3, experts reviewed and re-annotated disputed areas, confirming over 99% agreement for most classes.Initial annotation processIn Stage 1, two independent groups of annotators manually annotated the dataset at the pixel level. A pixel-wise agreement matrix was computed to quantify the consistency between the two groups. The corresponding agreement and disagreement percentages, along with a contingency table showing the number of pixels in agreement and disagreement across all classes, are provided in the supplementary Tables S2 and S3. Disagreements were observed across nearly all land cover classes, except for Brick and Road. In the Water class, significant confusion occurred with Farmland and Marshland, leading to disagreement rates of 3.4% and 5.66%, respectively, as provided in Supplementary Tables S2 and S3. This confusion was largely due to the merging of water regions with adjacent farmland, as well as the frequent presence of aquatic vegetation in Bangladeshi ponds and lakes, which may visually resemble farmland. The Farmland class also showed disagreements with Road, Rural Built-up, Marshland, and Meadow. Roads that run alongside or through agricultural plots often create class ambiguity. Additionally, early-stage or post-harvest crop fields may visually resemble meadows, contributing to misclassification. For the Forest class, disagreements were relatively minor but primarily occurred with Rural Built-up areas. In Bangladesh, rural houses are commonly surrounded by dense vegetation, leading to partial overlap between forested and built-up regions. This resulted in a 3.93% disagreement rate for the Forest class. Among all classes, Road had the lowest agreement at 88.18%, while Forest had the highest at 95.24%. Representative examples of these disagreement scenarios are shown in Fig. 6. Many of the initial inconsistencies were addressed in Stage 2, with the remaining disagreements resolved during the final review by remote sensing experts.Intermediate annotation processIn Stage 2, all regions of disagreement identified in Stage 1 were isolated from the rest of the dataset for detailed re-examination. These areas were given additional attention to resolve inconsistencies. Specifically, 200\(\times\)200 pixel regions where annotator Groups 1 and 2 disagreed were flagged for review. Each of these regions was re-evaluated in consultation with the original annotators assigned to that section. Following these discussions, the annotators refined the annotations using a pen-based input on a 24-inch iMac display, utilizing Adobe Photoshop to delineate overlapping class boundaries at the pixel level with higher precision. The updated pixel-wise agreement and disagreement percentages are reported in the Supplementary Tables S4 and S5. These revised metrics demonstrate a marked improvement in annotation consistency, with the maximum disagreement reduced to 4.2% as shown in Supplementary Tables S4 and S5.Fig. 6Disagreement in annotation between Group 1 and Group 2 members. Disagreement 1: Some of the water areas have been missed by Group 2. Disagreement 2: One group 1 member annotated the long thin region as water (blue), whereas one group 2 member marked it as a road. In Bangladesh, numerous areas are characterized by roads or rivers running through vast farmland. Map created by the authors using data from31. Maps were modified using the Lucid web application (https://lucid.app/).Full size imageFinal annotationIn Stage 3, a subset of the previously agreed-upon regions between annotator Groups 1 and 2 was evaluated by a team of remote sensing experts with prior experience in LULC annotation. A random sample comprising 10% of the agreed area from each class was selected for assessment. Expert annotations were then compared with the corresponding annotations from the initial groups. As provided in the Supplementary Tables S6 and S7, all classes demonstrated pixel-wise agreement exceeding 99%, except the Urban Structure class, which had an agreement of 98.585%. Based on these results, the full set of agreed-upon regions from Groups 1 and 2 was retained without further modification. The supplementary Tables S6 and S7 include a table showing agreement percentages between group consensus and expert annotations. The remaining portion of the dataset, consisting of regions where Groups 1 and 2 initially disagreed, was fully re-annotated by the expert group. A summary of agreement and disagreement between the expert annotations and those from Groups 1 and 2 is also included in the supplementary Tables S6 and S7. Since the experts re-annotated all disagreement regions, their labels were retained for those areas. Upon completion of this stage, the full annotation process was finalized. The class-wise pixel distribution for the eleven LULC classes is illustrated in Fig. 8a.In situ assessmentAccurate classification of LULC is critical for applications such as urban planning, environmental monitoring, and resource management. In-situ synchronization or validation is required to validate the acquisition time and appropriateness of the data47. To verify the reliability of annotations in the BOLM dataset, an in-situ validation48 was conducted across the Dhaka Division in December 2019. The assessment focused primarily on the outskirts of Dhaka, where rapid urban expansion is occurring. A comprehensive plan was developed to cover diverse landscape types, including urban cores, rural settlements, agricultural zones, industrial areas, riverbanks, and natural ecosystems. Equipment included high-resolution cameras or smartphones, notebooks, and the Gaia GPS app to record precise coordinates. More information has been given in Table S9 of the supplementary materials about the in-situ validation. The images taken for the validation of each site are available in the dataset repository.During the field visits, observers documented land cover characteristics such as vegetation, water bodies, and built structures. GPS-tagged photographs were taken to compare real-time ground conditions with the dataset annotations. The team visited 13 representative sites (marked in Fig. 3), covering approximately 1 km radius around each location. Most observed LULC features showed strong agreement with the annotations derived from Bing imagery. In cases where discrepancies were noted, such as areas undergoing recent land use changes, the regions were assigned the “Unrecognized” class to exclude them from training and analysis. This helped ensure that only verified and temporally consistent areas were included in the final dataset.Validation using independent sourceTo ensure the reliability of the BOLM dataset, we conducted an independent validation using high-resolution historical imagery from Google Earth’s Historical Images. This served as a complementary step to the expert-based and in-situ validation methods detailed earlier. Remote sensing experts visually inspected numerous regions across the annotated area using 2019 Google Earth imagery for the same year as the Bing satellite data used for annotation, to verify the spatial accuracy and semantic correctness of the labeled classes. This process involved comparing annotated land cover boundaries with corresponding landscape features visible in the Google Earth interface. Key land cover types such as water bodies, urban structures, roads, and vegetated areas (e.g., forests, meadows) were cross-checked for consistency. Discrepancies, if found, were flagged for correction or assigned to the Unrecognized class if ambiguity remained. Our methodology aligns with recent validation practices, such as those presented by Brown et al.49, who employed a similar approach by supporting expert annotations with visual interpretation using Google Earth images. Incorporating such external reference data added an important layer of verification and support to the robustness of our ground truth annotations.However, a few discrepancies were noted, such as in Gazipur, where newly built structures had replaced farmland. These transitional zones were labeled as ”unrecognized” in the ground truth. To maintain annotation integrity, such areas were excluded from the training dataset during preprocessing, ensuring the model was not exposed to outdated or ambiguous land cover data. Maps were generated using QGIS version 3.10.1039 and the Lucid web application (https://lucid.app/). The authors took pictures of the landscapes in the figure.Full size imageConversion from 11 to 6 classesTo mitigate the challenges posed by severe class imbalance in the original 11-class land cover dataset, we restructured the labels into six aggregated categories for benchmarking purposes. Deep learning models are inherently data-driven and require sufficient representation of each class to learn discriminative features effectively. However, as shown in Fig. 8a and Supplementary Table S8, several original classes such as Brick Factory (1.31% test), Road (1.02%), and Urban Structure (2.86%) constitute a very small portion of the total pixel distribution. These underrepresented classes exhibited extremely low segmentation performance, with some achieving 0.0000 IoU and F1 scores, and others, like Road, scoring only 0.0388 in IoU. Training on such imbalanced data increases the risk of bias toward majority classes and poor generalization on minority categories.To address this, semantically and spectrally similar classes were merged to form broader and more balanced high-level classes. The new Built-up class combines Urban Structure, Urban Built-up, Rural Built-up, and Brick Factory, all representing anthropogenic surfaces. Likewise, the Meadow class includes both Meadow and Marshland, which share similar spectral and contextual characteristics. In contrast, classes like Farmland, Forest, and Water were retained in their original form due to their adequate spatial coverage and distinct semantic identity. As shown in Fig. 8b and Supplementary Table S1, this restructuring significantly improved class balance and training robustness.To ensure a comprehensive evaluation, we trained and tested our models on both the original 11-class and the aggregated 6-class configurations. While the 6-class setup achieved more stable performance due to reduced class imbalance, the 11-class results are included to demonstrate model behavior under highly imbalanced conditions. Full per-class scores and distributions are provided in the supplementary figure S1.Fig. 8Area Percentage of the 11-class and 6-class dataset.Full size imageMethodologyModel architectures for LULC segmentationTo benchmark LULC segmentation performance, we evaluated three different deep learning models: DeepLabV3+, U-Net, and UniMatch. DeepLabV3+ is a state-of-the-art architecture known for its encoder-decoder design and use of atrous convolutions to capture multi-scale contextual information. U-Net is widely used for its skip connections that preserve spatial detail, making it effective for capturing fine-grained features. UniMatch, on the other hand, leverages weak supervision and consistency regularization to achieve robust results even with limited labeled data. Together, these models provide a comprehensive assessment of different segmentation approaches for urban environments in developing regions.DeepLabV3+DeepLabV3+ has been used for LULC segmentation in all experiments. It is a state-of-the-art semantic segmentation architecture developed by Google. DeepLabV332 by using an encoder-decoder structure and employing atrous (dilated) convolution50 to preserve spatial resolution while capturing multi-scale contextual information. The atrous convolution can be expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} y[i] = \sum _{k} x[i + r \cdot k] \cdot w[k] \end{aligned}$$where \(x\) is the input feature map, \(w\) is the convolutional kernel, \(r\) is the dilation rate, and \(i\) and \(k\) are spatial indices.We selected DeepLabV3+ due to its demonstrated effectiveness in supervised semantic segmentation tasks and its suitability for handling complex urban and rural landscapes in our LULC dataset. Benchmarking with DeepLabV3+ provided a solid baseline for comparison with other models like U-Net and UniMatch, ensuring that our analysis remains thorough and adaptable for future research.U-NetU-Net33 is a widely used architecture for semantic segmentation, known for its encoder-decoder structure with skip connections that help retain spatial detail. The skip connections combine low-level encoder features with decoder outputs and are expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} y_{\text {decoder}} = f_{\text {decoder}}(y_{\text {encoder}} \oplus y_{\text {skip}}) \end{aligned}$$where \(\oplus\) denotes concatenation. In our study, U-Net was used to benchmark segmentation performance against DeepLabV3+. The model performed competitively, particularly in built-up and meadow classes, and achieved strong average F1 scores. This confirms U-Net’s effectiveness as a reliable baseline for LULC segmentation.UniMatchUniMatch34 is a recent weakly supervised segmentation framework designed to leverage limited labeled data by enforcing consistency in model predictions under perturbations. Its consistency regularization can be expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} \mathcal {L}_{\text {consistency}} = \mathbb {E} \left[ \Vert p_{\theta }(x) - p_{\theta }(x') \Vert ^2 \right] \end{aligned}$$where \(p_{\theta }\) is the model’s prediction and \(x\) and \(x'\) are perturbed inputs. In our experiments, UniMatch demonstrated strong average IoU performance and competitive results in forest, built-up, water, and farmland classes, highlighting its robustness in LULC segmentation.Pre-processingThe input and ground truth images are divided into patches of size 513\(\times\)513 pixels for network training. Certain areas in the ground truth are difficult to label due to ambiguity or lack of information; these regions are marked as unrecognized and represented with black pixels in both the input and ground truth masks. For training, patches are extracted using a sliding window approach with 75% overlap in both horizontal and vertical directions to ensure sufficient coverage and context. During testing, non-overlapping patches are used. The paired input and ground truth patches are then fed into the DeepLabV3+ model for semantic segmentation.Evaluation metricsTo assess model performance, first, we calculate a confusion matrix51,52,53, which is an \(N \times N\) matrix, where N is the number of target classes. It is used for evaluating the performance of machine learning models. Each row of the matrix represents the instances in a predicted class, while each column represents the instances in an actual class (or vice versa).We derived the Intersection over Union (IoU) and the F1 score following the approach in46,54, which leads to a comprehensive evaluation. Both metrics were derived from confusion matrices constructed using predicted and ground truth pixel labels. These metrics offer a more balanced assessment compared to overall accuracy, particularly in the context of class imbalance commonly observed in LULC datasets.Intersection over Union (IoU) is defined as the ratio between the overlap area and the union area of the predicted and ground truth regions for each class:$$\begin{aligned} \text {IoU} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Positive} + \text {False Negative}} \end{aligned}$$This metric evaluates the spatial agreement between the predicted and actual land cover areas.F1 Score is the mean of precision and recall and provides a measure of a model’s accuracy by balancing both false positives and false negatives:$$\begin{aligned} \text {F1} = 2 \cdot \frac{\text {Precision} \cdot \text {Recall}}{\text {Precision} + \text {Recall}} \end{aligned}$$where:$$\begin{aligned} \text {Precision} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Positive}}, \quad \text {Recall} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Negative}} \end{aligned}$$We excluded overall accuracy in our evaluation, since it can be misleading for imbalanced datasets where dominant classes often influence the metric despite poor performance on minority classes.Experiment setup & resultsExperiment settingsThe Dhaka city region (marked by the red rectangle in Fig. 3) is used as the test set, while areas outside this region but within the blue rectangle are used for training. Experiments are conducted using three types of input data: index images, channel-combined images, and Bing RGB images. All training images are generated using a 513\(\times\)513 sliding window with 75% overlap. A batch size of 8 and 25 training epochs was used across all experiments. Testing uses the same window size without overlap. DeepLabV3+ serves as the segmentation model for all the experiments but we employed U-net, UnimatchV2, HRNet-V2 and Segmenter ViT-16 only with the Bing RGB(BOLM) dataset for final comparison in Table 4. For index-based inputs, each index (NDVI, NDWI, RVI) is stacked into a 3-channel format. Channel-combination experiments use specific RGB arrangements from Sentinel-2 bands. The final experiment uses the full-resolution Bing imagery to assess segmentation accuracy at finer detail. In this section, we describe all the experimental results.Bing & sentinel-2A benchmark comparisonTable 3 Scores for 5 classes of all the image types.Full size tableThe segmentation results for the three index images (NDVI, NDWI, and RVI) and composite images (ATM, FCI, SWI, SentinelRGB) are shown in Table 3. These results highlight the strengths of each image type in segmenting the five LULC classes.Among the index images, NDWI achieves the highest IoU of 0.20 and F1 score of 0.32 for the forest class. It also performs best in detecting water, with an IoU of 0.24 and an F1 score of 0.51. NDVI shows the best performance for built-up and farmland classes, with an IoU of 0.52 and F1 score of 0.68 for built-up, and an IoU of 0.35 and F1 score of 0.51 for farmland. RVI has a slightly better F1 score for meadow at 0.52. While the average F1 scores of RVI and NDVI are similar, NDVI has a slightly higher average IoU of 0.30, suggesting it is the most balanced index image for overall land cover segmentation. NDWI, on the other hand, excels in water detection.For the composite images, SWI consistently achieves the highest average IoU and F1 scores of 0.35 and 0.50, respectively. SWI performs best for the forest class with an IoU of 0.22. Built-up areas are segmented equally well by ATM and SWI, with an IoU of 0.56, but SWI has slightly higher F1 scores, indicating better accuracy. Water is also segmented more accurately in SWI, while ATM shows the highest IoU for farmland at 0.48. For meadow, SentinelRGB achieves the highest IoU of 0.25.Overall, composite images outperform index images, likely due to the richer information provided by their three channels. Although SentinelRGB is commonly used for LULC mapping, it does not achieve the same performance as SWI and ATM. This suggests that combining different spectral indices and features in composite images helps achieve better class separability.The BingRGB dataset shows the highest performance among all datasets, with an average IoU of 0.44 and an average F1 score of 0.60. This indicates that the high-resolution RGB images from the Bing satellite contain more detailed information, leading to superior segmentation performance across all five LULC classes.To summarize, SWI emerges as the best composite image for Sentinel-2A data, with consistently high scores across most classes. NDVI stands out as the most balanced index image, while NDWI remains the best for detecting water. BingRGB, with its high-quality imagery, achieves the best overall segmentation results, highlighting the impact of data quality and resolution on classification accuracy.Baseline comparisonsFig. 9Normalized Confusion Matrices for DeepLabV3+, Segmenter ViT 16, U-Net, and UniMatchV2.Full size imageWe have included normalized confusion matrices for each baseline model, following the approach adopted in recent literature51,52,53, to provide a detailed assessment of class-wise segmentation performance. The Fig. 9 presents normalized confusion matrices comparing the performance of DeepLabV3+, Segmenter ViT 16, U-Net, and UniMatchV2 on land use and land cover (LULC) classification. UniMatchV2 and U-Net show relatively balanced performance across all classes, with U-Net achieving strong discrimination in built-up and water regions. DeepLabV3+ shows higher misclassification in forest and meadow categories, often confusing them with built-up and farmland. All models maintain perfect classification for the unrecognized class. Overall, UniMatchV2 demonstrates slightly better consistency in forest and farmland segmentation, while U-Net maintains high accuracy in built-up and water classes.The confusion matrices in Fig. 9 show two major misclassification patterns that are consistent across all four models. First, there is a significant confusion between meadow and farmland. This happens because it is often difficult for even advanced deep learning models to distinguish between the two, especially in early crop seasons when farmlands appear barren and resemble natural meadows. However, our in-situ assessments confirmed that the ground truth labels were correct in those cases. Second, there is noticeable overlap between built-up and forest classes. This is particularly common in Dhaka city, where rooftop gardens are widespread, and in rural areas where trees often lean over the roofs of single-story houses. These subtle and small-scale features are difficult for the models to classify accurately.The results in Table 4 reveal that UniMatchV2 achieves the best overall performance with the highest average IoU of 0.51. It also leads in the forest, built-up and water classes, demonstrating strong segmentation across major LULC classes. U-Net shows competitive results, particularly excelling in F1 scores for built-up (0.81), water (0.73), and meadow (0.43). U-Net also achieves the best IoU for meadow at 0.30 and an average F1 score of 0.65, which is higher than DeeplabV3+. The Segmenter ViT-16 did best on the farmland class with merginal improvements over the UnimatchV2 and very similar on the built-up class.Table 4 Performance comparison of DeeplabV3+, U-Net, UniMatchV2, Segmenter ViT-16, and HRNet on different LULC classes.Full size tableDeeplabV3+ delivers solid and consistent segmentation, with an average IoU of 0.44 and an F1 score of 0.60. While it does not outperform the other models in individual classes, it remains a reliable option for general land cover mapping. Overall, UniMatchV2 emerges as the best-performing model in IoU scores, while U-Net shows a balanced and precise segmentation ability, particularly in challenging classes like meadow. These findings highlight the strengths of each method in different aspects of LULC segmentation.LULC comparison with world bankTable 5 Classification results for different train and test data combinations using DeepLabV3+. The highest values per column are highlighted.Full size tableThe results in Table 5 show class-wise and mean Intersection over Union (IoU) scores for different train and test combinations using the BOLM and World Bank datasets. The highest values for each class are highlighted. The model trained and tested on the BOLM dataset achieves the highest mean IoU of 0.49 and outperforms all other combinations in forest, water, and farmland categories. When evaluated on the World Bank test set, the BOLM-trained model still performs reasonably well, achieving a mean IoU of 0.43. In contrast, the model trained on the World Bank dataset yields lower mean IoUs of 0.20 on BOLM and 0.30 on its own test set. Note that Forest values are marked as N/A for World Bank training scenarios due to the absence of forest annotations in that dataset.LULC for full BangladeshAfter training the DeeplabV3+ model, we are now able to generate detailed LULC maps for the entire country of Bangladesh. Figure 10 presents LULC predictions for three example districts: Cox’s Bazar, Rangamati, and Netrokona. The model differentiates major land cover classes, including built-up areas, water bodies, forests, farmland, and meadows. For each district, the LULC distribution is visualized, highlighting the strong capability of the model to provide accurate and detailed land cover information at the district level. These predictions show the potential of the trained model to support large-scale mapping and analysis of LULC across Bangladesh.Fig. 10Prediction of (a) Cox’s Bazar, (b) Rangamati and (c) Netrokona districts using our trained model on DeepLabV3+. Map created by the authors using data from31.Full size imageDiscussionWe conducted a series of experiments to benchmark model performance using our annotated dataset. The annotated labels were found to be sufficient for training large-scale deep learning models with reliable accuracy. Initially, Sentinel-2A images with various band combinations and index-based transformations (e.g., NDVI, NDWI) were used with our ground truth to evaluate model performance on low-resolution data (10 to 20 meters/pixel). Subsequently, Bing imagery was used to test high-resolution input. Results showed that segmentation performance with Bing images consistently outperformed Sentinel-2A experiments.These findings highlight practical considerations for the remote sensing community in developing countries. Our annotated dataset can be used with both high-resolution RGB imagery (e.g., Bing, Google) and freely available lower-resolution multispectral satellite data (e.g., Sentinel-2A), depending on the application’s requirements. High-resolution imagery is preferable when accuracy is critical (e.g., for urban expansion or annual land cover change detection). However, due to limited temporal availability and access restrictions of commercial platforms in developing countries, lower-resolution Sentinel-2A data may be more suitable for tasks requiring frequent monitoring, such as crop analysis55.It is also important to note that Bing and Google imagery only provide RGB channels and do not include near-infrared (NIR) or shortwave infrared (SWIR) bands. As a result, common remote sensing indices like NDVI and NDWI cannot be calculated from these sources. To address this, our annotations can be paired with Sentinel-2A imagery that includes spectral bands for calculating such indices, enabling broader LULC applications.Although Bing imagery offers very high spatial resolution, it has significant limitations in both metadata transparency and temporal coverage, especially in developing countries. This reduces its effectiveness for applications that require regular temporal monitoring or change detection. Lesiv et al56. conducted a comprehensive analysis of Bing and Google Earth imagery and found that their update frequency is inconsistent and often delayed by several years in less economically prioritized regions. Additionally, Bing imagery provides only RGB bands, lacking crucial spectral information such as near-infrared (NIR) and shortwave infrared (SWIR), which are essential for distinguishing between spectrally similar land cover types. In contrast, multispectral data from platforms like Sentinel-2 offer higher spectral resolution and regular temporal updates, enabling more accurate LULC classification57. Khaldi et al58. further emphasize that multispectral time series are critical for capturing seasonal variability and long-term land cover trends, highlighting a key shortcoming of RGB-only imagery such as Bing. Since the BOLM dataset is georeferenced, it can be readily aligned with Sentinel-2 or other multispectral datasets acquired at matching time periods. This enables researchers to take advantage of BOLM’s fine spatial detail while complementing it with spectral and temporal insights from other platforms, thereby extending the dataset’s applicability to broader LULC and environmental analysis tasks. Despite the inherent spectral and temporal limitations of Bing, its high-resolution imagery remains highly valuable for fine-grained annotation and urban structure delineation, especially in dense and heterogeneous regions where lower-resolution imagery fails to capture critical detail.Bing imagery was chosen as the primary source for annotation due to its higher spatial resolution, which is essential for distinguishing fine-scale land cover features in densely populated urban environments like Dhaka. Although Bing provides only RGB bands, prior studies (e.g., Ramos et al.46) have shown that high-resolution RGB imagery can achieve competitive segmentation accuracy, particularly when detailed pixel-level annotations are available. While Sentinel-2 offers multispectral data and higher temporal frequency, its 10–20 m resolution is insufficient for capturing fine-grained urban heterogeneity. Moreover, as Brown et al.49 demonstrated, expert annotations guided by RGB imagery (including Google Earth) can support reliable land cover mapping even without full spectral information, provided that spatial detail and acquisition date alignment are maintained.In our study, the Bing imagery used for annotation was captured in April 2019. To mitigate the issue of infrequent updates, we cross-validated the imagery against historical Google Earth data from the same period. This helped verify temporal consistency and detect areas with recent land use changes. Ambiguous or recently modified regions (e.g., under construction) were excluded or labeled as “Unrecognized” to avoid introducing noise into the training data. While Bing’s update frequency limits its use for time-series monitoring, its spatial precision makes it highly suitable for baseline mapping and detailed model training in data-scarce regions.BOLM’s high-resolution imagery and detailed, pixel-level annotations enable better class separation and generalization, especially in complex urban-rural environments like Dhaka city. While the World Bank-trained model reports a higher IoU for the Built-up class, this is partly due to a trade-off: the dataset lacks a Forest or Tree class, which removes the ambiguity between vegetation and built-up areas. As a result, many vegetated regions near urban zones are misclassified as Built-up (shown in supplementary figure S1), artificially inflating the score. If a Forest class were included, the model’s ability to distinguish these overlapping features would be significantly challenged, especially given the coarse annotation style and limited class definitions in the World Bank dataset. In contrast, BOLM explicitly defines such classes, allowing the model to learn finer distinctions between urban structures and surrounding vegetation, an essential capability in unstructured and densely mixed land use settings common in developing countries.Both Bing and Sentinel-2 imagery serve complementary roles when used with the BOLM dataset, depending on the application focus. For monitoring, time-series analysis, and remote sensing applications, Sentinel-2 can be aligned with BOLM’s georeferenced annotations to leverage its rich spectral bands and frequent temporal coverage. This is particularly effective for tracking seasonal land cover changes, assessing vegetation health, or conducting disaster resilience studies using spectral indices like NDVI and NDWI. In contrast, for deep learning benchmarks and tasks aligned with the computer vision community, BOLM paired with Bing’s high-resolution RGB imagery is better suited. The fine spatial detail of Bing facilitates pixel-level segmentation, feature learning, and model evaluation for urban environments, where detailed object boundaries are crucial and multispectral information is not a requirement. This contrast highlights BOLM’s flexibility across disciplines: supporting vision-based model development on Bing imagery, while also enabling spectral-temporal analyses when paired with Sentinel-2, thus broadening its utility in both computer vision and remote sensing research.The findings of Rahman et al.23 highlight challenges in applying this dataset to other regions due to differences in building materials, urban patterns, and settlement textures. For example, informal areas in Dhaka differ in appearance from those in Cairo or Mumbai, leading to varied segmentation performance across cities. Models like DeepLabv3+ perform best when trained and tested on the same city but may struggle to generalize to cities with distinct urban morphologies. This underscores the need for domain-adaptive methods to ensure consistent segmentation performance in cross-city applications.The model was first trained and tested on Sentinel and RGB datasets using DeeplabV3+ to understand if Bing RGB data offers better segmentation performance. In Table 4, we compared different baselines, including U-Net, Segmenter ViT-16 and the weakly supervised UniMatch model. This comparison aimed to see whether the segmentation scores could be improved using other models. The results show that standard benchmarks like U-Net perform very well, and even weakly supervised approaches such as UniMatch demonstrate strong performance. Although this study focuses on DeeplabV3+ to explore the benefits of atrous convolution for capturing spatial detail, the findings remain model-agnostic. Any better-performing model can be integrated into this workflow for improved results. Considering that newer transformer-based models are capable of capturing global context more effectively, future research can explore these architectures to build more robust segmentation models for LULC mapping.ConclusionThis paper provides high-resolution pixel-wise LULC ground truth annotations for Dhaka metropolitan city and its surrounding area. It covers an area of around 4392 square kilometers of the Dhaka region centered at Dhaka metropolitan city. This BOLM dataset can serve as LULC ground truth for eleven classes(eleven classes: Farmland, Water, Forest, Urban Structure, Urban Built-Up, Rural Built-Up, Road, Meadow, Marshland, Brick Factory, Unrecognized) for a developing country. It contains both rural & urban areas. Additionally, several experiments have been performed to establish baseline performance with Bing and Sentinel 2 A data for five major LULC classes: forest, farmland, builtup, water, & meadow. As Sentinel 2 A provides multi-channel data, index images, and different combination images are also used for our experiments for LULC. The investigation suggests that Bing data consistently outperformed the Sentinel 2 A data in any form with a significant margin. However, if the high-resolution image is not available, short-wave infrared (SWI) from Sentinel 2 should be used to get the best performance with the deep models.The BOLM dataset holds strong potential to support future advancements in land use and land cover harmonization as well as global urban mapping research. Its high-resolution pixel-level annotations offer a valuable benchmark for deep learning models across diverse geographic and socio-economic contexts. By aligning BOLM with multispectral sources such as Sentinel-2, researchers can integrate fine spatial detail with rich spectral information, enabling consistent cross-regional classification and temporal monitoring. This interoperability facilitates the development of standardized LULC products that are essential for harmonization efforts across developing and developed regions. Furthermore, BOLM’s detailed representation of heterogeneous urban and peri-urban environments provides a robust foundation for refining global urban mapping algorithms, improving their adaptability to unstructured landscapes, and enhancing the accuracy of urban extent and growth assessments worldwide.

Data availability
              
              This dataset has been made available online here under the Creative Common (CC) license. Te direct link is:https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/LLR3RR.
            Code availability
              
              Custom codes were written to process this dataset. The RGB image is required to convert into an Index image as it is required in the architecture. Also, to enhance the performance of the model and eliminate possible confusion from the dataset, the unknown part of the label needs to be projected on the input image. If the paper is accepted, the link for the codes will be published here.

I due uccelli facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, finanziato dall’Unione Europea
The post Ancora due Ibis eremita uccisi a fucilate appea
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Il bracconaggio continua a decimare una specie vicina all’estinzione Due Ibis eremita (Geronticus eremita), appartenenti ad una specie in pericolo critico di estinzione — scomparsi in Europa nel XVII secolo e reintrodotti grazie a un progetto di conservazione LIFE riconosciuto a livello mondiale — sono stati abbattuti il 16 ottobre a Dubino (Provincia di Sondrio, Lombardia), poco dopo aver attraversato il confine durante la migrazione. Un intervento immediato da parte delle autorità è stato possibile grazie alla stretta collaborazione tra l’associazione Waldrappteam, che gestisce il progetto, i Carabinieri Forestali e la Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola.I due Ibis, Zoppo e Zaz, facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, che vede Natura Viva come suo unico partner italiano ed è finanziato dall’Unione Europea. Si tratta infatti della prima iniziativa al mondo volta a ristabilire una specie migratrice nel suo storico areale europeo, ripristinando un comportamento migratorio culturale ormai perduto. Dal 2004, giovani Ibis allevati dall’uomo vengono guidati dalle colonie riproduttive che si trovano a nord delle Alpi fino al sito di svernamento in Toscana (Oasi WWF di Orbetello), assicurando che imparino la rotta migratoria per i viaggi futuri. La storia dei due Ibis Zoppo era un pionere tra questi uccelli. Nel 2017 aveva seguito con successo un ultraleggero da Überlingen, attraversando le Alpi fino all’Italia. Nel 2020 era diventato il primo Ibis eremita sessualmente maturo, dopo oltre 400 anni, a tornare indipendentemente nel sito di riproduzione sul Lago di Costanza. Un traguardo di inestimabile importanza per la creazione di una nuova colonia europea. Zaz, nata in natura a Überlingen nel maggio 2025, stava imparando quest’anno la rotta migratoria proprio da Zoppo — seguendolo passo dopo passo nel suo primo viaggio verso sud. All’inizio di ottobre 2025, la coppia aveva lasciato il sito riproduttivo ed era entrata in Svizzera, tentando più volte di attraversare le Alpi nel Cantone dei Grigioni. Il 16 ottobre, erano finalmente riusciti a superare la dorsale alpina principale nei pressi del Piz Gallagiun, a quasi 3.000 metri di altitudine. Poco dopo, si erano posati in un prato nei pressi di Dubino per cercare cibo — e sono stati uccisi a fucilate meno di un’ora dopo essere entrati in Italia. Petizione caccia Firma anche tu per dire Stop alla caccia selvaggia Aderisci all'appello Quasi tutti gli Ibis eremita del Progetto sono equipaggiati di trasmettitori GPS, che ne consentono il monitoraggio in tempo reale. Ciò ha permesso a Waldrappteam di allertare immediatamente le autorità. I Carabinieri Forestali di Lecco e Sondrio, con il supporto della Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola, hanno avviato un’indagine approfondita e recuperato i trasmettitori dei due Ibis. Sono stati sequestrati armi, munizioni, dispositivi elettronici ed una licenza di caccia ad un sospettato, che ora dovrà rispondere di accuse tra cui uccisione di fauna protetta e possesso illegale di armi. Ibis eremita in volo Il bracconaggio mette a rischio specie già minacciate Dure condanne arrivano anche dai vertici del mondo della conservazione.“Il bracconaggio resta la minaccia più grave per l’Ibis eremita in Italia,”ha affermato il Dr. Johannes Fritz, Direttore di Waldrappteam Conservation & Research. “L’uccisione di due Ibis eremita a meno di un’ora dal loro arrivo in Italia è un promemoria doloroso della grave minaccia che il bracconaggio rappresenta per la biodiversità e dell’urgenza di combattere questo crimine.”L’episodio avviene in un momento di forte preoccupazione riguardo al Disegno di Legge 1552, una proposta legislativa italiana che mira ad estendere la stagione venatoria anche a periodi cruciali per le specie migratrici.Un grazie ai Carabinieri Forestali ed alla Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola per la loro azione rapida e professionale. Questo caso evidenzia l’importanza della collaborazione coordinata tra organizzazioni di conservazione, forze dell’ordine, autorità e volontari — in linea con l’Articolo 9 della Costituzione italiana, che impegna la Repubblica a proteggere la natura e la biodiversità per le generazioni future.

items.body:
Ge Vernova: indicazioni geografiche ed operative per evento di Green Team Building a Lucera (FG)

27.10.2025

condividi:

Gentilissimi Partecipanti all'evento di team building, questa pagina è pensata per fornirvi tutti i dettagli tecnici sull'attività che andremo a realizzare. Le attività di Team Building, promosse da Rete Clima, sono progettate per favorire la crescita delle foreste italiane e della biodiversità. Un modo concreto per dimostrare l’impegno verso la responsabilità ambientale, dando corpo alle strategie aziendali ESG.

In aggiunta a quanto specificato di seguito, per qualunque necessità o approfondimento ci possiamo sentire tramite email o telefono (contatti in fondo alla pagina).

Indicazioni generali

Quando: 2 dicembre 2025 - con data di backup in caso di mal tempo fissata per il giorno 16 dicembre (stesso orario).

Dove: ritrovo alle ore 10:30 presso l'area adiacente alla Masseria Sant'Agapito - A Rural Odyssey, dove vi accoglierà il personale di Rete Clima: vedi Link Google Maps

Iscrizione all'evento: clicca qui per iscriverti

Programma

saluti e introduzione alle attività forestali: illustrazione delle corrette tecniche forestali per la piantagione degli alberi, distribuzione DPI (guanti da lavoro) e dei materiali di lavoro;

Avvio delle attività;

Conclusione dei lavori, chiusura dell'evento e saluti.

Raccomandazioni

Abbigliamento: comodo/sportivo, con scarpe robuste o sportive, meglio se da trekking. Utile preparare un "abbigliamento aziendale", con magliette, cappellini, grembiuli e altri capi personalizzati con il logo aziendale.

Campagna nazionale Foresta Italia: SDGs raggiunti e Patrocini

Di seguito i riferimenti relativi alle attività forestali che svolgeremo insieme:

L'attività è svolta nell'ambito della nostra Campagna forestale nazionale Foresta Italia®.

Contatti Team Rete Clima:
